Notes: "The main part of the study area is a military training area of about 145 km2, including 100 km2 of forest." "former opencast coal mines of large dimensions belong to the wolves´ present home range."  possible SP and SA overlap with Wagner 2012. WIld game abundant in area. High number of wild ungulates.
Protected_Area: "Here, the wolves are safe from permanent human disturbance"
Wolf_Notes: Rare but regular immigration of wolves from Poland into Germany after WW2. Wolves legally protected in 1990. Occasional occurrence for a few years, then first pair formed in 1998, with successful breeding by 2000. Areas adjacent to Muskau heath only occasionally visited by wolves. "The Muskau Heath is exactly the area where, in ca. 1800, the wolves still lived while extirpated from the rest of Saxony (Winkelmann 1996)." Prefer open landscape for hunting. Raised between 2-5 pups each year during the study.  The 2000 pups left natal territory in 2002,mand settled in the western portion of study area, then later split up with only 1-2 wolves remaining in that area. Pups from 2001 left but don't know where to (or when). If 2000's pups left in 2002, then in 2001 there wouldve been either 8-11 wolves total? Min 2 pups therefore min # of wolves would be 4.
Livestock_Notes: 6500 sheep in study area that graze in the summer months. almost all are grazed within twoo layers of electric fences 24 hours a day. A few livestock attacks have been reported. Cattle also present.
Wild_Ung_Avail_Name: Red deer (Cervus elaphus), roe deer (Capreolus capreolus), wild boar (Sus scrofa), mouflon (Ovis ammon musimon)

Notes: elk were primary prey for wolves and mule deer were primary prey for cougars
Protected_Area: Privately owned
Wolf_Notes: Recolonized study area in winter 2002. Bear trap pack averaged 5 wolves (range: 2-8)
Livestock_Notes: Not mentioned so presumably none
Wild_Ung_Avail_Name: elk (Cervus elaphus), mule deer (Odocoileus hemionus), white-tailed deer (Odocoileus virginianus), and moose (Alces alces)
Pred_Larger_Name: grizzly bears (Ursus arctos horribilis), black bears (Ursus americanus), cougars

Notes: Snow ranges from almost zero to several meters deep. Western Arctic Caribous Herd (WACH) is mostly migratory. Spring migration though study area to calving grounds and autumn migration out of area to the south.
Protected_Area: Game management unit 23
Wolf_Notes: Estimated wolf density was 12.9/1000km^2 in 1977. "Spring wolf densities increased from 2.7 to 4.4 wolves/1,000 km2 during 1987 through 1990, and then declined to 1.5 wolves/1000km2 following a rabies epizootic". Harvested yearly by hunters and game officials. Radio collared 86 wolves in 19 packs and relocated them on 1,830 occasions. Usually resident packs. Average winter territory size was 1372  +/- 175 km^2. Some packs followed caribou herds when moose densities were low. Average spring wolf weights in kg: Adult M=47.3, Adult F= 42.2, Yearling M= 46.2, Yearling F= 41.9, Pup M= 44.6, Pup F= 37.5 (for standard errors see table 1)
Wild_Ung_Avail_Name: Caribou, moose (Alces alces), Dall sheep (Ovis dalli), muskox (Ovibos moschatus)
Pred_Larger_Name: Brown bear (Ursus arctos), black bear (U. americanus)
Pred_Smaller_Name: Red fox (Vulpes vulpes), wolverine (Gulo gulo), lynx (Felis lynx)

Notes: has habitaat type descriptions but not quantitative
Protected_Area: Includes a natural park
Wolf_Notes: have pups (and thus high energy needs) in spring and summer. "The trophic position of the wolf in the study area is closer to a facultative specialist than to an opportunist species, because a facultative specialist may change from a key food item when other profitable prey is available (Glasser 1982)."
Livestock_Notes: Present. Horses, cattle, goat, sheep
Wild_Ung_Avail_Name: Roe deer, red deer, wild boar, fallow deer, mouflon

Study_Area: Yellowstone National Park Madison Headwaters area
Wolf_Notes: 37 wolves from 4 packs radiocollared over study period

Notes: Albertan wolves reported to be "somewhat larger than those in southern Ontario and Minenesota". 1500-2300 cattle graze within the study area between May-October
Wolf_Notes: There is significantly more wolf data than what is noted here, check paper for more. wolf density was 1 wolf per 92km^2 (14-15 wolves) in winter 1975 and one wolf per 42 km^2 (40 wolves) in 1979 (the population high), then goverment decided to control wolves and population droped to 13 wolves in 1980/81. 12% of wolves were lone wolves. mean summer territory size was 233km2 (range: 100-276) and mean winter was 424km2 (range: 198-572). Mean wolf pop increase between late winter-summer was 60%, mean winter pop loss was 30%. Min consumption rate for one pack over 51 days in winter was 0.12kg/kg wolf/day. # wolf packs with more than two wolves increased from 3 in winter 1975/76 to 6 in  winter 1978-1979. Mean midwinter pack size was 6, range 2-12. Mean 12% of wolf pop were lone wolves. Government wolf control conducted during late winter 1979-80. 6 is mean pack size. number of packs was 3-6, total number of wolves ranged from 13-40.
Wild_Ung_Avail_Name: Moose, Elk, Mule deer, white-tailed deer

Notes: Ibex is the only wild ungulate in the study area. Lack of marmots. Pikas and partridge like birds common
Coor_Given: 76° 20′ E to 35° 27′ N (town of Hushe, not center of study area)
Protected_Area: yes, livestock still graze their and 150 households (1200 humans)
Wolf_Notes: descend to lower altitudes ((<3000m asl) where the livestock is) from December-May (the study period) . group-living. use less steep and less rugged terrain, not cliffs. listed as ‘endangered’ in the red list of Pakistan Mammals. altitudinal range of at least 1000m asl to over 5000m asl. Greater flexibility whem it comes to habitat use and use of local ressources. 'least concern' species. ecologically flexible
Livestock_Notes: Abundant. See prey notes in sheet 4 for details
Wild_Ung_Avail_Name: Ibex (Capra ibex)
Pred_Smaller_Name: Red fox (Vulpes vulpes), Corsac fox (Vulpes corsac)

Notes: Upper elevation limit may be of adjacent area, not study area. Domestic livestock were rare in area (50 horses present in winter, no sheep or cattle)
Study_Area: North Fork Flathead River Glacier National Park
Protected_Area: No but adjacent to Glacier National Park
Avg_Snow: Annual sum of maximum snow depths were "used to classify winters as shallow-snow or deep-snow, with the distinction point at 300 cm. Winters 1985-86, 1986-87, 1987-88, and 1988-89 were shallow-snow (range =150-277, x = 223.5, SD = 47.3). Winters 1989-90 and 1990-91 were deep-snow (range = 320-325, x = 322.5, SD = 2.5)"
Wolf_Notes: wolves were reduced in BC and AB and extirpated from the GNP and surrounding areas by late 1930s. Began to recolonize area in 1982 after being listed as an endagered species in 1973 in the US. 31 radiocollared wolves from Aug 1984-July 1991. "The wolf pack consisted of 6, 12, 10, 10, 12, and 7 wolves in the early winters of 1984-85 to 1989-90, respectively. In summer 1990, the pack split into 3 packs containing 9, 7, and 2 wolves, dividing the former home range into thirds. We followed all 3 packs during winter 1990-91."
Livestock_Notes: Domestic livestock very rare: only 50 horses and only in winter
Wild_Ung_Avail_Name: White-tailed deer (Odocoileus virginianus), mule deer (Odocoileus hemionus), elk (Cervus elaphus), and moose (Alces alces)
Pred_Larger_Name: mountain lions (Felis concolor), black bears (Ursus americanus), and grizzly bears (Ursus arctos)

Notes: Hare and porcupine also present.
Study_Region: Homonym massif of Appenines towars Arezzo plains
Protected_Area: Half is a natural reserve
Snow_Period: Winters characterized by snowfall and snow melting (Snow stays less than 50 days per winter)
Wolf_Notes: Early winter pack size was 5 (based on howling surveys and snow tracking)
Livestock_Notes: Cattle and horses free range from June-Sept, sheeps and goats present year-round at low altitudes.
Wild_Ung_Avail_Name: Wild boar (Sus scrofa), Roe deer (Capreolus capreolus), Fallow deer (Dama dama)

Notes: Small mammals common.
Wolf_Notes: Early winter pack size was 4-5 (based on howling surveys and snow tracking)
Livestock_Notes: Sheep and goats present in open areas throughout the year. A few large herds of horses and cattle present near farms and villages in small numbers. Local climate allows livestock to be grazed on pasture year round.
Wild_Ung_Avail_Name: Wild boar (Sus scrofa), Roe deer (Capreolus capreolus), Fallow deer (Dama dama), Mouflon (Ovis ammmon musimon)

Notes: Audy Lake pack territory. 1977-78 was a mild winter while 1978-79 was a severe winter
Protected_Area: no hunting allowed in park but hunters frequently harvest along park boundaries
Wolf_Notes: partially exploited wolf population.  Three wolves (all pups or young of year) from the Audy Lake (AL) pack were captured. Until 10 November the pack consisted of 5 wolves. Thereafter it remained 3 (1 adult of each sex and a pup).
Livestock_Notes: No mention
Wild_Ung_Avail_Name: Moose (Alces alces), Deer, Elk (Cervus elaphus)

Notes: Baldy Lake pack territory. 1977-78 was a mild winter while 1978-79 was a severe winter
Protected_Area: no hunting allowed in park but hunters frequently harvest along park boundaries
Wolf_Notes: Average wolf weight = 32.7kg (no details on mass). partially exploited wolf population. Territory size was 290 km^2. Early winter pack size was 8 and then reduced to 5 after Dec 12
Livestock_Notes: No mention
Wild_Ung_Avail_Name: Moose (Alces alces), Deer, Elk (Cervus elaphus)

Notes: 53% cultivated land, 20% wetlands, 10% brushlands, 10% forests (deciduous and coniferous), 7% pasture and grasslands. Study area consists of Agassiz National Wildlife Refuge and three adjoining state wildlife management areas (Elm Lake, Eckvoll and Mudlac Wildlife Management Areas) and the surrounding agricultual land. The 2 consecutive winter  before the study were severe, possibly one of the reasons why the deer and moose pops were declining.
Protected_Area: Some? unclear
Wolf_Notes: Wolf population has persisted in area since early 1980's and there is a nearby population source of dispersing wolves. Part of the Eastern Timber Wolf Recovery Project?
Livestock_Notes: Cattle and pig farms in non-wildlife reserve areas. Only one pig farm and pigs only available as carcasses through the farms carcass dump
Wild_Ung_Avail_Name: Moose (Alces alces), White-tailed deer (Odocoileus virginianus)

Notes: Snow average is either <200 or <100, depending on if snow does (<100) or doesn't (<200) count as rainfall
Protected_Area: "Conservation area"
Wolf_Notes: Very rare. Ecological info is practically non-existent according to author.
Livestock_Notes: abundant
Pred_Smaller_Name: Eurasian lynx (Lynx lynx), Red fox (Vulpes vulpes), Tibetan fox (Vulpes ferrilata) and golden jackal (Canis aureus)

Protected_Area: 27 km2 area within site is protected (hunting is banned)
Wolf_Notes: confirmed using DNA from scats, snow tracking and wolf-howling surveys
Livestock_Notes: a number of (mostly) sheep farms surrounding the study area
Wild_Ung_Avail_Name: Roe deer (Capreolus capreolus), Wild boar (Sus scrofa), Red deer (Cervus elaphus) (occasionally recorded only after 2007)

Notes: "Relatively well-preserved habitats and low anthropogenic pressure". No Africn swine fever cases recorded in the mountain yet
Protected_Area: "protected border area" unclear in legal environment protections. Year round hunting
Wolf_Notes: Wolf has always been present in the mountain. Two small wolf packs in 2016 and 2018, one with 4 individuals each, one with eight. Wolf density was 0.02 in 2018, 0.02 in 2019, and 0.06 in 2020 (based on REM). the larger pack persisted to 2020 and beyond .
Livestock_Notes: domestic horses are all thats mentioned
Wild_Ung_Avail_Name: Roe deer, wild boar

Notes: 50.2% scrubwood, pine wood 8.4%, abandoned olive groves and pastures(partially re-colonized by wodd and bushes) 9.2%, set-aside grassland 3.9%, marshland/wetlands 3.8%, crops (mainly cereals and sunflower) 24.4%. "among carnivores, the red fox Vulpes vulpes, the Eurasian badger Meles meles, the wildcat Felis silvestris, the stone marten Martes foina and the pine marten Martes martes." "rich community of meso-mammals (8 species among rodents, lagomorphs and carnivores)"
Protected_Area: yes - extent not clear
Wolf_Notes: a pack settled in area in 2015, a second pack settled north of the ombrone river in 2017 (may visit north portion of study area)
Livestock_Notes: 3 wild ungulates: 2 livestock. Free ranging cattle and horses, locally and irregularly moved through pastures and some pine/scrubwood
Wild_Ung_Avail_Name: Roe deer, wild boar, fallow deer

Notes: SA saw recent increases in wild ungulate densities
Protected_Area: Natural park
Wolf_Notes: Drastic decline in range and numbers led to legal protectionin the 1980's and are now recovering. Wolf is the only top predator in the area, so they believe that wild ungulate presence in the diet is reflective of wolf kills and not of scavenging.
Livestock_Notes: Cattle, sheep, goats, and pigs. Mostly sheep. See prey notes in sheet 4 for detai,s
Wild_Ung_Avail_Name: Red deer, Roe deer, Wild boar
Pred_Smaller_Name: Red fox (Vulpes vulpes) mentioned, Domestic/wild cat is mentioned in diet analysis as a category but no scientific name was given so unsure if they mean feral or an actual wild cat species

Protected_Area: Provincial park
Wolf_Notes: 15 wolf packs across the 3 regions. average wolf density over 5 years = 0.038/km^2. Average pack size was not significantly different between regions. Algonquin wolf is one of the smallest subspecies of gray wolf (average male= 29 kg (authors unpublished data) and "significanlly smaller than other wolves in the Great Lakes region". "extraterritorial movement was not recorded, possibly because a migratory deer population was not present to draw wolves beyond established territories." Declines in wolf numbers between 1960-1970s, possibly due to deer decline but wolf mortality was also high at this time.
Livestock_Notes: None mentioned
Wild_Ung_Avail_Name: Moose (Alces alces), white-tailed deer (Odocoileus virginianus)

Protected_Area: Provincial park
Wolf_Notes: 15 wolf packs across the 3 regions. average wolf density over 5 years = 0.040/km^2. Average pack size was not significantly different between regions. Algonquin wolf is one of the smallest subspecies of gray wolf (average male= 29 kg (authors unpublished data) and "significanlly smaller than other wolves in the Great Lakes region". Declines in wolf numbers between 1960-1970s, possibly due to deer decline but wolf mortality was also high at this time.
Livestock_Notes: None mentioned
Wild_Ung_Avail_Name: Moose (Alces alces), white-tailed deer (Odocoileus virginianus)

Protected_Area: Provincial park
Wolf_Notes: 15 wolf packs across the 3 regions. average wolf density over 5 years = 0.052/km^2. Average pack size was not significantly different between regions. "Algonquin wolf is one of the smallest subspecies of gray wolf (average male= 29 kg (authors unpublished data) and "significanlly smaller than other wolves in the Great Lakes region". "In 1990-1991 and 1991 -1992, 8 of the 10 region C wolf packs (80 % ) spent extended periods, ranging from several days to months, outside of natal territories (Forbes and Theberge 1995). This wolf movement was related to the seasonal emigration of park deer to a deer yard located 15 km from the park." Declines in wolf numbers between 1960-1970s, possibly due to deer decline but wolf mortality was also high at this time.
Livestock_Notes: None mentioned
Wild_Ung_Avail_Name: Moose (Alces alces), white-tailed deer (Odocoileus virginianus)

Notes: All wild cervids except chamois were extirpated from area during WW2 . Reintroduced in 1962 and sufficiently restored to allow hunting again in 1985. Livestock present, flocks of sheep and goats and herds of cows free range
Wolf_Notes: Number of wolves ranged 7-15 (1.7–2.9 wolves/100 km2). Legal protection since 1972, after wolves nearly extirpated from area. 2 packs verified in area during study period: Gran Bosco pack and Bardonecchia pack. Snow tracking and howling techniques to evaluate wolf status, highest number of wolves per pack recorded was the value used for that season.
Wild_Ung_Avail_Name: Chamois (Rupicapra rupicapra), roe deer (Capreolus capreolus), red deer (Cervus elaphus), wild boar (Sus scrofa), alpine ibex (Capra ibex) and moufflon (Ovis orientalis musimon).

Notes: Has % of area of different cover types (shrub, deciduous, pasture, mixed forest, etc). Given that 3 scats were geneticlaly ID'd to red fox, they must be present in at least one study area.
Protected_Area: yes - restricted agriculture and forestry activities
Wolf_Notes: Generalist-opportunistic predator, diverse and adaptable feeding strategies. Carpatian mountains are one of the largest wolf refuge areas in europe. Heavy persecution until 1975, still hunted until it became legally protected in 2021. Evidence of resident packs, but no reliable estimate of wolf density or pack data.
Livestock_Notes: Extensive grazing by highly abundant sheep, cattle, and goat. highest livestock density of the four areas
Wild_Ung_Avail_Name: Red deer, Roe deer, Wild boar

Notes: area is 23000 but 17250 moose habitable

Protected_Area: 300 km^2 is protected and it is illegal to graze cattle there

Notes: For sheet 9 only
Wolf_Notes: Wolf abundance fluctuated between 40-106 wolves, mean pack size 10-11.

Study_Area: Bow Valley of Banff National Park (Bow Valley BNP)

Notes: does not list other predator, only know cougar because it was also a study animal. 23000 but 17250 moose habitable
Snow_Period: Oct-Apr, as late as May/June at higher elevations
Wolf_Notes: Two wolf packs were monitored via aerial and ground-based telemetry. Wolf pack sizes ranged from 7–11 animals, with the exception of the winter of 2000, when one of the two packs was reduced to two individuals. During 2001, in addition to the resident wolf packs, we monitored 2 groups of dispersing wolves consisting of 1–2 animals from nearby and resident packs
Wild_Ung_Avail_Name: elk (Cervus elaphus), mule deer (Odocoileus hemionus), small number of bighorn sheep (Ovis canadensis) and mountain goats (Oreamnos americana)

Notes: "small variety of potential prey, the almost total absence of competition from other predators". Should the feral horse be considered wild? paper says they've been there since the pleistocene. They are considered semi-feral by management but this is heavily disputed.
Protected_Area: "Site of Community Importance and Special Conservation Area under the European Union’s Habitats Directive (92/43/EEC)"
Wolf_Notes: Legally protected. Galicia is an important area for wolves, and they have persisted there at a steady population level for the past 200 years. In 2014 there was 84 packs or 2.8 packs per 1000 km2. They say that they only got scats from one wolf pack per area but no info on the specific wolf packs or how they not it was a single wolf pack was given.
Livestock_Notes: Galician feral horses disputed wether they are feral/wild or just loosely domestic. "The livestock density on agricultural land outside the forest is medium in comparison to the other two study areas"
Wild_Ung_Avail_Name: Galician feral horse (Equus ferus atlanticus), Roe deer (Capreolus capreolus), Wild boar (Sus scrofa)

Notes: 90.7% forested (in depth forest composition given). Nested within BPF. "The climate of Białowieża is transitional between continental and Atlantic types, which makes it rather variable". Brown bear extirpated from area? **European bison and moose were "only occasionally recorded in BNP, so the census did not show their presence" should they be included in 'ungulates_avail'? Poaching likely occurs to some extent
Protected_Area: Strictly protected, no forestry harvest or hunting allowed since 1921. No motor transportation allowed in the park and tourist access is regulated and restricted to a few footpaths
Wolf_Notes: No hunting of wolves here since 1921. Hunted in Poland until 1989. "45 wolves (three times the contemporary numbers) were recorded in the western (now Polish) part of BPF in 1935" therefore ~15 wolves during the study period (but this might include BPF).
Livestock_Notes: None
Wild_Ung_Avail_Name: Roe deer (Capreolus capreolus), Red deer (Cervus elaphus), Wild boar (Sus scrofa), (available in general area but not recorded during censuses: European bison (Bison bonasus), Moose (Alces alces))

Notes: 61% forested, also gives forest composition. Heavily exploted for timber since 1915. Forestry activities has changed the forest composition to being predaominantly more coniferous (area is naturally predominant in deciduous but coniferous is more economically valuable) "Man-made changes in the forest structure (towards predominance of coniferous stands and young age classes) greatly impoverished the food supply for some species of ungulates." Tall wire fence along border seperates the Polish and Belarusian parts of the forest, ungulates cannot cross the fence. Brown bear extirpated from area? hunting season is in winter
Protected_Area: No - timber exploitation, replanting and game management
Wolf_Notes: Hunted in Poland until 1989. "45 wolves (three times the contemporary numbers) were recorded in the western (now Polish) part of BPF in 1935" therefore ~15 wolves during the study period (but this might include BNP)
Livestock_Notes: No mention
Wild_Ung_Avail_Name: European bison (Bison bonasus), Moose (Alces alces), Roe deer (Capreolus capreolus), Red deer (Cervus elaphus), Wild boar (Sus scrofa)

Wolf_Notes: Average adult male= 46.4kg (SE = 0.86kg, range=35-67kg), average adult female = 39.3kg (SE=0.7kg, range=27-50kg), body mass data from wolves in the Carpathian mountains. Notes: There may be more wild ungulate species in area (paper just says that they are the two most abundant, not that they are the only ones). Wild forest reindeer went extinct in FInland in the early 1900's but reapperd in the late 1950's as their population expanded from Russia. Forest cover is 80% of land area (93% of forested land area is commercial forest) half of the swamps have been drained. Young successional mixed forests are common. Mean human density in area is 2/km^2 but <1/km^2 within wolf territories
Snow_Period: permanent snow mid Nov-early may. Snow depths peak in march
Wolf_Notes: 3 packs studied. In 1999 there were 7 adults and 9 pups. In 2000 there were 15 adults and 20 pups. Rare in the study area before 1999. in 1998 only 5 wolves (a pack of four and a lone female) were present in area. Wolf numbers declined to 14-16 due to hunting and juvenile dispersal. Annual territory sizes ranged from 600-1700km^2. Territories 2 and 3 partially overlap. Territory 1 is the only one within reindeer wintering range.
Livestock_Notes: No mention
Wild_Ung_Avail_Name: Moose, Reindeer

Notes: 70 cougars, 64 grizzlies, and 200 black bears, per 1000 km^2 (external estimate)
Study_Area: North Fork Flathead River Glacier National Park
Protected_Area: No, hunting allowed by permit
Wolf_Notes: 10 wolves/1000 km^2 (winter density in a portion of the study area, external estimate). Number of wolves in South Camas pack: 1992=5, 1993=10, 1994=11, 1995=10, 1996=12. Number of wolves in North Camas pack: 1992=11, 1993=7, 1994=3, 1995=4, 1996=5. There were also two other packs but no names given, eventually only one pack was left of the two, the number of wolves in each of the packs was: 1992=3 and 4, 1993=5 and 6, 1994=7, 1995=10, 1996=6. Most kills located were from the north and south camas packs. Average wolf pack size of all packs (3-4) from all years was 7 (range: 3-12), North Camas and South Camas packs only (average both all years= 7.8, range: 3-12)
Livestock_Notes: No mention

Notes: Anatolian wild sheep at low numbers (40-80) despite frequent re-stocking of sheep, possibly due to wolf predation. Brown bear and lynx only occur sporatically. Wild boar are hunted for population control (minimize agricultural damage), not hunted for human consumption (religious reasons). Carcasses are either collected for hunting dog food  or left for scavengers. Ungulate pops (Except wild boar) in region declining over past two centuries due to hunting and poaching, but now beginning to recover
Wolf_Notes: Pack is " composed of two adult and one to two sub-adult wolves per year". Apex predator in turkey, has never been extirpated in anatolia. 6000-8000 in Anatolia
Livestock_Notes: Not available in winter but otherwise highly abundant, free grazing and corrals. Heavy over grazing on eastern half in non-winter. West half is supposed to be protected and it is illegal to graze livestock there but it still happens.
Wild_Ung_Avail_Name: Anatolian wild sheep (Ovis gmelinii), Red deer (Cervus elaphus), Wild boar (Sus scrofa)
Pred_Smaller_Name: Golden Jackal (Canis aureus), Eurasian lynx (Lynx lynx), Red fox (Vulpes vulpes), Jungle cat (Felis chaus)

Notes: Study area= 39.5% woods, 29.4% scrublands, 17.1% cultivated fields, 13.7% pastures.  "In the area there were small and interspersed villages, with large portions of uninhabited land due to depopulation of the mountain areas (human population density: 19 individuals per km2)." "The use of livestock was limited, and even more limited was the use of other categories such as small mammals, medium-sized mammals and fruits; consequently, the diet showed a low breadth." " In addition, the abundance of livestock and farming methods differ greatly from the Alps to the Apennines and in different parts of the Apennines, creating great variability in the availability of livestock in Italy and, consequently, in the trophic habits of the wolf (ISTAT 2003)."
Wolf_Notes: In the 1970's, only 100 wolves in italy and only present in two remote areas of south central appenines. Legal protections led to wolves recolonizing the study area in the late 1980's. "Wolves colonized the area in the late 1980s (the first wolf was illegally killed in 1987), when the wild ungulate guild was composed mainly by wild boars (600 individuals shot per year), while roe deer was beginning to colonise the area; fallow deer was present in a few sites, and red deer was absent. At that time, the occurrence of wild ungulates in the wolf diet was 19.4% (wild boar 17.1%, roe deer 0.8% and fallow deer 1.6%) and that of livestock was 25.6%. Other important food categories in the wolf diet were vegetables (59.7%), small mammals (26.4%), invertebrates (23.3%) and medium-sized mammals (10.1%), the sum of the percentage frequencies exceeding 100 because of the contemporary occurrence of more than one category in the same sample (MERIGGI et al. 1991, 1996; MILANESI et al. 2012). Wolves are present in the study area with five main packs of 4.8 (SD = 2.17) individuals on average, and a small number of lone wolves estimated by snow-tracking, wolf-howling and camera-trapping. Legal control of wolves is not practiced in the study area; however, 4–6 wolves were illegally killed between 2005 and 2012."
Livestock_Notes: "Livestock (cattle, goats, sheep and horses) was free-grazing from April to October with births occurring on the pastures and inspected one time per week. The main productive aim was meat production." "Prevention methods such as the presence of large shepherd dogs, adequate fences, anti-wolf fences and regular surveillance of pastures are rarely adopted but have been increasing in the last 2 years."
Wild_Ung_Avail_Name: Red deer, fallow deer, roe deer, wild boar

Notes: for sheet 5.1 only

Roztocze has heavily fragmented forest interspersed with large agriculture areas and villages. Solska forest is compact forest. Beavers present but relatively low. Free ranging domestic dogs are bundant in natural habitats across Poland. Lynx here prey almost exclusively on roe deer (Author cites another one of their papers)
Protected_Area: Roztocze National Park (84.8 km^2) and multiple Natura 2000 special areas of conservation
Wolf_Notes: Present in the region throughout the second half of the 20th century. Heavily persecuted, then protected in Poland in 1998. At least 5 wolf family groups recorded in area at the beggining of the 21rst century. Wolf territories spanned both Roztocze and the Solska Forest (so the areas were considered as one). Part of the baltic subpopulation of wolves.
Livestock_Notes: "During vegetation season, cattle, horses and sheep are grazed on pastures surrounding forest tracks, especially in the Roztocze region (Dziaducha 2021). Furthermore, the Roztocze National Park supports small herds of heritage breeds of horses, cattle and sheep (altogether ca. 120 individuals) grazed on pasture inside the park."
Wild_Ung_Avail_Name: Moose, roe deer, red deer, wild boar, fallow deer
Pred_Smaller_Name: Eurasian lynx (Lynx lynx), Red fox (Vulpes vulpes)

Notes: "The study period (1990-2000) was characterised by profound political changes and economical regress. This situation favoured uncontrolled exploitation of wild ungulates, which led to their fast, many-fold decline." 78% is natural habitat, man transformed (field, pastures, meadow, human settlements, roads) covers 22-31%, dry meadows are 16% of whole region and 73% of the agricultural land. "Though we have no precise data on ungulate hunting quotas and poaching intensity, the information obtained by interviewing the local hunters as well as our observations on the remnants of the poached moose and wild boar in the study area allowed us to roughly estimate that, since 1992, the killing rate of ungulates by humans could have increased 5 to 10-fold in comparison with earlier years and it remained heavy until 1995."­
Snow_Period: 1.5-2 months of constant snow, snow period Late oct-mid april.
Wolf_Notes: "In the early 1990s, wolves were relieved from heavy control but few years later, when heavy damage to livestock caused complaints from farmers, hunting on wolves intensified". Table 1 has wolf density by year
Livestock_Notes: "The majority of these villages were small (5-26 houses and 9-67 inhabitants), but two were fairly large (49 and 84 houses, 147 and 242 inhabitants). Farmers mostly kept cows, pigs, hens, dogs and cats, whereas horses, sheep and geese were less common. Two collective farms ('kolkhoz') operated in the two large villages, and they had many cows (110 and 280), pigs (50 and 120), and horses (15 and 40)."
